text:
My husband and I had our anniversary dinner here and it was amazing! The service from the time we walked in was incredible. They sat us immediately and the waiter was very prompt. The chef, Jeff, greeted us personally and even presented our dessert for us!
My husband had the chicken, which was flavorful and juicy. I had pasta with shrimp, which I recommend highly! We had the pear bruschetta appetizer and I would also highly recommend it!
It was a very enjoyable evening and plan to go back again!

It was a very enjoyable evening and plan to go back again!

text: My hubby surprised me with a little "staycation" getaway for my birthday. We spent the night at an Airbnb in Parkville, MO & we were so surprised to learn that the little Italian place on the corner called Frank's served breakfast! We were intrigued, so we gave it a shot. It was delicious. I had the Chicken Alfredo Omelette, my husband had the Tuscany Frittata, and we split a side of French toast. It is a charming little restaurant. Friendly staff, and a lovely atmosphere. We will definitely be back! I'm excited to try it for dinner as well!

text: Best EVER garlic bread!!!!  Literally made my day! Ha! That pesto garlic dipping sauce was divine with that perfectly cooked bread. I got a yummy delicious HUGE plate of bowtie chicken, enough for lunch tomorrow as well. One son got Sicilian pizza, good (not really spicy as listed) but also plenty for leftovers. Other son got lasagna, also good and husband got a beef pasta.... deburgo, very spicy, perfect for his taste. Nice that the calamari came with both warm marinara and cool lemon aioli, as my family was split on preference, but stealing garlic bread almost resulted in a fork in the hand! Only disappointment was that sweet tea came as tea with sugar packets, which any tea lover knows doesn't dissolve well when tea is cold and... my husband was asked if he wanted parmesan cheese and pepper on his meal but when server came back she said that the parmesan "hadn't been taken out yet," asking if just black pepper was okay? What? An odd comment...as if he wasn't worthy of getting the cheese out after he was asked. Otherwise, we were overall pleased with our experience.

text: Paulo and Bill is a fantastic restaurant! My boyfriend and I made eating here our anniversary dinner tradition several years ago, and it does not disappoint. The bow tie pasta is incredible, and the chicken alfredo pasta is great, too. I've never had food here I didn't like. However, the real star of the show is the phyllo brownie - you just can't come here without getting one!! You can come to Paulo and Bill dressed up for a special occasion, and students sometimes come in dressed up for proms or homecoming, and yet if you are wearing a t-shirt and jeans, you won't feel too out of place, either. It's versatile and the perfect restaurant for any occasion. Great food, great service. Thanks, Paulo and Bill!

text: PUMP is a great place to have brunch. I came here for my birthday and absolutely loved it the second I walked in. I heard about this place when I went to Vegas. They have a pump in Vegas at the Caesars Palace, and I fell in love with that place, so I was excited to hear that there was one closer in West Hollywood. When you first walk in, it’s like you’re entering a secret garden. We were seated right away in their beautiful outside area. I highly recommend eating outside to get the whole experience; instead of eating inside, it literally felt like you’re eating in a garden. Our waiter was super nice, super friendly, and was efficient. My husband and I ordered drinks and appetizers. Then we ordered our food, and everything was delicious and yummy. It was a really great romantic experience. The only thing that could’ve been better was their dessert menu. Also, I was confused about the parking situation. We didn’t see a valet or a parking lot. We found street meter parking across the street. With this, make sure to give yourself enough time to find parking and to make your reservation.

text:
Trendy restaurant that’s part of the Vanderbilt empire. Come here for the pretty decor and to say that you’ve been here. The food is mediocre, but the photo ops are plentiful. Wear something cute!

Metered street parking (2 hour limit). It’ll be tough to find any free parking close to the restaurant (it’s right in the heart of WeHo). Credit cards accepted. Reservations available and there’s a 90 min limit for the dining experience. Gender neutral restrooms. Outdoor dining available.

Food-wise, everything is overpriced for what it is. The burrata appetizer came with 4 slices of toast and tomatoes, but only a small portion of burrata. I got the lox benedict, which came with four small potatoes, but a surprisingly good amount of salad. The avocado toast was a bit soggy, but it’s a good vegetarian option. We didn’t do drinks because we were recovering from the night before, but note that the sparkling water is ~$12. Service was nice but slow. In short, it’s a popular tourist spot where you can take fun photos and try to see if you’ll spot anyone vaguely famous, but don’t come here expecting particularly good food.

text:
Okay wooooow! I was not expecting this to be what it was. Well, food wise anyhow I was pleasantly surprised. Anything on the West Hollywood strip, I’m expecting to be a tacky, but in the spirit of location, a super fun experience. It is decked out, very Hollywood. I don’t watch whatever show they have, but for those who do and are coming for a visit, I say hit this place. The folks I sat next too at the bar were super excited to be there. In short, good food, drinkable drinks, and beautiful atmosphere.
I’ve only been here once and sat at the bar, so I cannot speak to the full dining experience, but the bar was very mediocre, they have the look but not the talent which made it disappear (or maybe just not the resources to make good drinks). If I ever return I’m drinkin wine. Full menu is available at the bar, it is open seating. Prices are a little high, but your paying for location so forget about it.

THE FOOD: nothing salty, some items may need salt. Low on the crazy flavor scale. Pretty presentation.

Fish and Chips: for the win! Fish was lightly seasoned, cooked to perfection, and the fries were goody good good. Appreciate and liked the tarter sauce and malt!

Burger: basic and boring, but the fries again, good good.

Popcorn Shrimp: for the win!

Potato Salad: 100% a joke. I the chef made this so be funny. Like, just to see who would eat it or return it. We returned it. They didn’t remove it from our bill…speaks volumes.

text:
We absolutely loved it! I was really surprised about the quality of the foods. I thought it might be mediocre because they probably don't have to worry about getting guests because of the TV show. The food was outstanding and I'm super high maintenance about quality! We came for the happy hour and got 4 different appetizers. Best fries I have ever had with a great dip. The wontons had quite a bit raw tuna and they were also paying attention to the presentation. The taste was really divine and rounded with balsamic reduction, pomegranate and avocado. The shrimp was garnished with mango. They had quite a few people who were serving so you didn't have to wait and they were super friendly,   and everyone was quite attractive.

The only 2 things that could be improved are: 1. They only serve happy hour items in the garden, on 2 tables and then those tables didn't have a server (but one guy was willing to serve us). 2. It was my birthday and when I got the reservation it asked for occasion and I wrote birthday and I kinda thought someone would at least say "Happy Birthday" to me. It's ok, but it just would have been nice.

text:
The waitstaff is amazing!! Angela is fantastic! And I'll admit the hand pinched taco was tasty! (Beef with parm)  The house frozen margarita was incredibly sweet. Which I like, but the alcohol is very light. And from here on out, just NO.

The waitstaff and busser is the only reason they got 2 stars!

Do not walk, run!  The salsa was interesting. It was okay and had carrot bits in it. Odd, but I like to try new things. I got the spinach dip. The large. The most disgusting dip I've ever had. It tastes like the cheese was the cheapest they could find and I couldn't tell if the spinach was from a can or a cheap frozen brick. Other than that it was beyond bland. There was an odd taste I've had before but I couldn't even eat 1/8 without the margarita. (And sadly I will gorge on cheese dip.) So, no to the salsa, no to the spinach cheese dip, and the chips are eh. The frozen margarita, was really weak, definitely not worth $6, but sweet if that's how you like it. I do. 😊 The pinched taco... okay, I really enjoyed that! The waitstaff - someone needs to poach them!!! This place doesn't deserve them.

Edit:
The frozen margarita,  I still stand by that it is sweet, but I have more of a buzz than I realized. So the alcohol's just kind of hidden.  I will say I would indulge in another frozen Margarita here.

The "busser" I referred to, come to find out, is the manager. Not expected, but he was a hard worker, great personality, friendly, and very welcoming.

I will admit, he said several people commented on the dip saying it tasted weird and took it off no issues or real questions.

I personally don't plan on coming back. But if they were slow and I was bored and wanted to chat with the staff, I would eat a taco and have a margarita. If you live close by, and love to support Mom and Pop places as I do, I say give it a try and leave your experience on here. Maybe I just caught them on a really off day. Or maybe I'm a little spoiled. 🤷‍♀️

text: I haven't eaten here in over 20 years. But I grew up in the northland & decided to get some take out tonight for the nostalgia. I just picked it up 10 minutes ago & look at it! Have you ever seen a more disgusting box of food? Burnt beans, burnt rice & stadium nacho cheese? That's supposed to be a burrito, an enchilada, a tostada, beans & rice. Online ordering was fine, staff was nice at pickup, but the food is completely inedible. I'm not the type to go back & ask for a refund, but I will never go anywhere near this place ever again. I honestly can't believe they would serve this to people.

text:
Walked right in and was seated right away. They immediately brought us out chips, salsa and queso. The queso was great and the salsa had a different texture but was good. It’s rare to find places that start you off with free queso. They honestly have the best horchata I’ve had. The food had great flavor and the portions were perfect. The rice was a little dry for my liking, but I typically never eat the rice anyways. Service was great and they had refills ready to go. The pricing was around $10-12 per person, which was well worth it.

Plenty of parking and located right behind Kelly’s, next to the car wash.

text: We loved this out of the way Mexican restaurant. It's worth a trip to Basehor, Kansas. In fact, it is why we came! We had been told it was a family owned restaurant with lots of regional specialities we wouldn't find elsewhere, and that was exactly right! I had the Shrimp Romero and my husband had the Presidente combo, which he couldn't finish, it was so generous. The salsas for the chips seemed homemade. The creamy green salsa was especially good. We will definitely make the 40-minute trip again!

text: I am somewhat of a snob when it comes to German food.  Spending a lot of time over there, I have had some wonderful experiences, and have struggled to find food made the right way.  This place nailed it.  Everything is perfect, from the Schnitzel to the Wursts to the spaetzle.  The sauerkraut, and the kartoffelsalat were wonderful as well.  At first glance the menu is pricey but well worth it once you receive your meal. I think the Jaeger Schnitzel sandwich is an absolute winner.  They do good job with Polish food as wel--the pierogies, and the stuffed cabbage were wonderful.  This place is an absolute hidden treasure with a lovely river view.

text: Awesome! Dined on the deck beside the Rancocas Creek, but it was all about the food! My son's(18 & 21) and I started with pierogi and kartoffelpuffer that were delicious and then moved on to the main course. Two of us had the Best of the Wurst Platter, which I included a picture of, that had 6 different kinds of sausages, with sauerkraut and spaetzle. Neither of us finished it all. He came closer by eating 5 of 6. I ate the major part of all 6. Of course we brought our leftovers home. Will be going back and taking beer. They are BYOB. CASH ONLY!

Two of us had the Best of the Wurst Platter, which I included a picture of, that had 6 different kinds of sausages, with sauerkraut and spaetzle. Neither of us finished it all. He came closer by eating 5 of 6. I ate the major part of all 6. Of course we brought our leftovers home. Will be going back and taking beer. They are BYOB. CASH ONLY!

text: The ambiance was very romantic for our wedding anniversary. The server was also very nice and helpful with the menu. I got the fillet 4oz combo with 3 bourbon maple shrimp. I was underwhelmed when I saw how small the steak looked and it was well done not medium. It was also dry and needed a sauce. The shrimp was flavorful and tasty. The sides were good but nothing to rave about. My husband got the cajan spiced pan roasted fillet which was seasoned nicely but was very clean..small portions all around. The au gratin was lukewarm and the mushroom was on top of the steak and not really a side. The dessert of the 7 layer coconut cake was very moist and good but I don't care for the passion fruit coulis.

text:
I wish I loved this meal, but honestly I could have had better in Boston and that's not saying much.

The baked potato was delicious and very flavorful, but the strip steak with blue cheese crust was all panko breadcrumbs and very little blue cheese. The steak was also a bit tough for the $39 price tab.

Service was also very slow. 40 minute wait for a table that never came so I sat at the bar instead and then waited another 10 minutes to have my drink request taken.

The glass of red wine I chose was out of stock, so I had to choose something different and waited another 10 minutes for someone to ask if I wanted a drink. Surprisingly, the meal came out quickly, in about 15 minutes, but having to wait nearly 1.5 hours for an okay steak and a delicious baked potato was disappointing.

The restaurant was busy, but the two bartenders (and one additional bartender / waitress that kept floating in and out of the bar) with a devoted barback should be able to handle a dinner crowd.

text:
Been a long time since I've been here, but this place is certainly worth treating yourself to for special occasions. Are they pricy? yeah, but if their target is for folks to come here to celebrate anniversaries and good news they fill the role perfectly.

I usually order the exact same thing over and over at restaurants. I'm a little picky and I like what I like.. J Alexanders is a different story. I could order at random and experience some amazing flavors anywhere on the menu. Carrot cake has never sounded appealing to me.. I tried theirs and I'm in love. Cilantro lime shrimp was incredible. Exceptional lasagna.

I would have gone with a bread that wasn't completely dehydrated for the salmon dip but it was really great anyway.

The servers, hostess, cooks, managers, everyone at this joint is working hard to deliver a good experience and it pays off.

text:
Servers are all paying attention to you.  Not just one but sometimes 3 per table.  Had fish tacos with macaroni and veggie burger with salad and fries.  Dessert chocolate bunt cake and pumpkin pie.

House made lemonade is sour-ly delicious

Fish tacos are perfectly fried and the sauce they have in the tacos really makes it taste better.

Salad is good, but the fried croutons with it is just yum!

Veggie burger is pretty thick, has flavor but isn't too dry.  The fries are like drugs.  Once you start you can't stop.

Dessert
Chocolate bunt cake is lovely.  Perfectly moist and sweet that it doesn't overpower the vanilla ice cream.  Sweet but not super sweet.  If that makes sense.
Pumpkin pie, is really simply done without added surger.  The pie crust is wonderfully done where you can't tell where it ends and the pumpkin moose begins.  The whipped cream on top is airy and goes great with the pumpkin flavor.

text:
Homegrown GA: where hospitality meets quality

This bustling Atlanta suburb diner has been a staple in the community for generations it seems. From the moment you pull up, you can see what to expect. Old school restaurant, friendly staff and a small but thorough menu.

Breakfast is served all day, and to be honest it’s substantial enough to carry you all day. Ask for the house special and you’ll be offered “The Comfy”. An open faced chicken biscuit with fresh sausage gravy on top. Add a side of potatoes if you like, but by no means is it necessary.

Don’t be discouraged by a wait, it moves quick and won’t leave you disappointed. Enjoy some coffee, the nostalgic signs and art that fill the walls, the friendly conversation with staff and the amazing smells coming out of the kitchen.

In short, this is a must go when in Atlanta.

text: Worth the wait. We waited outside for around 20 minutes as it drizzled. The picnic tables were shared by multiple families. The atmosphere was upbeat and friendly. Our names were announced via speaker when our table was ready. Inside is an amazing experience of Atlanta culture, that was a mix between hippie chic and yard hoarder fancy. The coffee was served piping hot so be careful! I mixed with chocolate syrup to make a mocha coffee. We enjoyed a skinny chicken plate that was served with fresh spinach which was absolutely wonderful. I favored the turkey round sausage over the chicken link sausage. My highlights are the grits and home fries which I opted to add the peppers and onions, and the pancake was big enough for the 3 of us to enjoy and tasted like heaven. Despite me not trying to eat at the same restaurant twice, this one will be revisited by me OVER and OVER again! Atlantalicious

text: New to Atlanta and had a friend visiting from DC this weekend so we wanted to find a good spot for breakfast and this place did not disappoint.  It’s a cute little eclectic spot with a great brunch menu.  We did have to wait 20-30 minutes for a seat but it was well worth it.  We started with fried green tomatoes which were delicious.  I had the fried chicken and waffles, the portion size was perfect and both items were very tasty.  The others with me had the biscuits and gravy, basic breakfast and fried chicken biscuit.  The only thing I wouldn’t recommend was the pancake, it was huge and looked good but tasted a little spongy.  Someone’s French toast that went by looked amazing so I will try that next time for sure.

text: I am obsessed. I stopped in Atlanta for the night while driving through and after looking online for breakfast spots this is what we decided on. I hope I get a chance to go back because it was so good. The staff was also super nice.

I ordered the steak hash and to my surprise it was seasoned well. I LOVE potatoes and the potatoes that came with my meal was so good. The only reason why I'm giving 4 stars is because my friends ordered scrambled eggs with their meal and it came out cold. They brought new orders out quickly but my friends think that the eggs were powered eggs. Idk because my eggs were over easy and perfect 👌🏽.
There were so many other things I wanted to try so I will definitely be back.

text: I think it's great when a restaurant can make up for a long, initial wait. This particular Lalibela location is ran and owned by a very sweet husband and wife. The establishment was clean and neatly decorated with Ethiopian based art. It was nicely lit for small group/small family style dining. They even have a bar. There were only 2 other dine-in parties seated when our group arrived. They were seated completely separate from each other and by the time we got our meals, we were the only diners there. Our service was kind and they answered any questions that we had. The food was delicious, especially the beef tibs, the shrimp dish, and the curried lentils! We got so full off of the injerra that the portions seemed almost endless. More importantly, the bathroom was spotless. I highly recommend, especially, if you want to try something new.

text:
Really love the concept! Some of the dishes were tasty while others were okay nothing too fancy,
If you are super hungry this type of style restaurant would be best bet as when you get seated you can start eating your food if you see anything you like on the conveyor belt.

We had appetizers and some decent sushi.
Some of the faves were:
Golden Sushi Roll
Tiger Roll
Texan Roll
Spicy Popcorn Roll
Shrimp Avocado Roll
CHEESECAKE

Inari was a little different but not too bold or sweet (neutral)
I gave it 3 stars because:
Cleanliness of the restaurant, it was a little smelly (outside of the raw food), even outside the restaurant.
We weren’t treated as a new customer, we were so lost until we had to flag down a waiter to help us understand and even then, we had to read over the instructions which are on the belt of how to order and how to take off plates on conveyor belt. We did eventually figure it out.
Lastly, their drinks options are very limited-  their tea (green) was not your typical tea it was not great - so we stuck with water.
Also, the place could use some updating.

text: Came in for lunch and we were honestly super surprised with the service and quality of the food for the price. The staff was friendly, and provided excellent service, seating us promptly, answering questions and explaining how to order and take sushi off the trays. During lunch it was a little packed so we did have to wait a couple rotations for some of the sushi but they have a great selection available and you have an express belt option where you can order straight to your table. We ate our fill of sushi, donuts and dumplings. They do have a pretty awesome reward system that you can get through their app and we even won some prizes! Would highly recommend for sushi lovers and those who just like to try something new.

text:
***Update 2023***
Food is good. Sad they never brought the banana tempura back. My issue is the rise in price over the years. I remember when the plates were a little over $2 each. Now, its almost $4. The ramen used to be about $5, now it's $10. Ridiculous price for a little bowl! We used to spend around $50, but now our total is $80, for less food! It's just not worth eating here anymore.

(2020)
Staff is friendly and the food is good. The tempura udon and tonkotsu ramen were delicious. Love the ponzu salmon and taiyaki with ice cream. Always coming back for more!

text: Love this place. The sushi 🍣 always tastes fresh AF. You can sit down and immediately start grabbing food off the rotating belt or order off the touch screen above you. If you order food of the touch screen it always arrives quickly, the dishes are consistently very tasty and always presented well. There's only been one dish I didn't like in the ten+ times I've been here... it was the fried squid or calamari dish. It was way over cooked and very rubbery. My favorite dishes are the rainbow and caterpillar rolls. I also really enjoy the hand rolls... They are probably the best deals in my opinion. The desserts are also really good, my favorite is the Fried banana 🍌. A must try if you're a fan of bananas. The fried donuts to me is a little over rated and not very impressive but still 'aight. The cheese cake is yummy and if the mochi wasn't frozen solid as a rock when I tried it I'd probably have enjoyed it more. The staff is always very friendly and there's always employees around to help if you have questions. I just hope they get a beer and wine license soon!

text:
Returned during COVID-19 and had a pleasant experience. Conveyor service is stopped — definitely the right move for everyone’s safety. All plates are made to order, and honestly i think the quality is fresher (you can already tell i loved ordering fresh— see below). The prep time can be longer than just grabbing from the conveyor belt, but for the safety and the freshness, i can take it!!
Menu-wise, i prefer all the belly (toro?) sushi to regular sushi. Their tamago is COLD - didn’t expect that... you should ask for wasabi and soysauce. Udon was decently good - i think better value than miso soup. Oh, i like mackerel as well, but it might be too fishy(?) for some people.
———

Fresh sushi if you order fresh :)

text: Very tasty buffet. A very nice and bright restaurant. It reminded me of Big Marina in Columbia Heights. Except they had the absolutely best gyro meat I ever tasted?! I just couldn't get enough. They also had a nice dessert selection and I got baklava. The parking lot is tiny and is shared with a halal market, so be prepared to park on the street if needed. Everyone was very friendly. I look forward to going back again!

completion: Very tasty buffet. A very nice and bright restaurant. It reminded me of Big Marina in Columbia Heights. Except they had the absolutely best gyro meat I ever tasted?! Everyone was very friendly. I look forward to going back again!

text:
Wonderful place and people. The service was down to earth but friendly. Aromatic pilafs of every kind graces the buffet. Sambusas, falafels, even steamed and fried fish for the pescatarians. Lots of ribs and grilled chicken for the carnivore. The dessert was uncannily good - creamy, gooey kunefe and baklava looking things hit the spot after a sumptuous buffet lunch.

There was also a cold plates table with tabouleh, salads, melons, dolmas, etc. i didn’t try it bc I need room for the pilaf and meat.

Everything seemed and tasted fresh. This is an incredible lunch deal and I am happy I discovered this place! A humble but confident venue that knows what it is doing.

PS - also western foods like spaghetti and meatballs and Mac cheese for the kids.

text:
Oh boy, I am sad that I found this place so late in life.

Probably one the best buffet deals you can find in MN. Piles of aromatic rice pilafs. Really fresh and tasty desserts. Not quite traditional pistachio baklava, but baklava-shaped with creamy gooey ness inside.

There were tons of stews but I really like okra so I downed the okra stew. Also the giant potatoes with sauce was great.

Service was great - down to earth and friendly. The decor is as it should be: diner-like without the fru fru extras. Mostly tables and standard stackable chairs.

Also there are western dishes like spaghetti and meatballs and Mac and cheese for the kids. I didn’t try them bc I got to get my fill of middle eastern foods.

Don’t miss out on this unassuming but diamond in the rough!

text:
Exceptional. We started out for Glam Doll Donuts, saw a Mexican bakery (Marissa's) down the street and got distracted. By the time we bought our Mexican pastries, it was lunchtime and Marhaba was across the intersection.

Understand one thing about Marhaba and you will fare much better there: don't expect much from their "American" food (looking at you, fried chicken wings). Everything else is very, very good. They do a Mediterranean buffet better than The Marina a few miles north. I didn't think that was possible and here I sit full an so very much corrected.

Things I needed seconds of (some of which I had, some of which I was too full to do again): baklava, catfish, lamb Kafka, tabouleh, gyro meat, meat samosa.

$42 for 2 adults and 2 preschoolers on some mysterious pay per year of the child's age system. So probably somewhere around $15/person with a soda. If the quality of the Mediterranean food wasn't so high, I would have dropped a star for the price. In this case , however, I have nothing to complain about: I feel I received an excellent value food:cost. I would repeat here on a date night without kids as the food is lost on their mac n cheese and chicken fingers minds.

text: I have known the proprietor, Mohammed, since he was the head chef at Big Marina on 49th and Central Northeast. He's a good kind and generous father, excellent chef, and you people Uptown are extremely lucky to have this place here end capping eat Street. This place is known for its Mediterranean fare, hummus, baba ganoush, tabouli, Gyros, sambusas, grilled chicken, roast chicken, Kafka, pot roast, BBQ rib tips, arguably some of the best mashed potatoes, three kinds of seasoned rice, countless other dishes. You need to bring an appetite, and expect to overeat if you plan on going with the all-you-can-eat buffet option. A more practical and dietary way, is to make your selections ala carte to go, even if you just sit down and eat. That way you take a measured amount, it controls the overeating, and it's more frugal. Mohammed doesn't mind either way, DIY card method means you're less likely to waste food, and as a Muslim, wasting food is considered a sign of disrespect for the gift of the meal, from Allah. I usually get a decent size lunch, for less than $10, ala carte. But enough with words let your eyes be the judge.

text: I went here on valentines with my partner for a date!! The food was delicious and the atmosphere was really enjoyable. It was our first time coming here and we both had a nice experience. It's a very cozy feel inside. We had reservations and got there about 3 mins early, they seated us quickly and gave us our menus and some bread. The customer service was really great. When walking to the restroom there's a big door to open into the hallway and a waiter nearby actually opened it for me, which I found very polite. The only complaint I have is that me and my bf both got steaks but our waitress didn't ask us how we wanted them cooked, my partner quicky told her how he wanted his cooked before she walked off after taking our order. Sadly, I didn't get to tell her how I wanted mine prepared since she walked off so quickly so overall my steak was cooked well done, which I didn't enjoy but it didn't ruin the taste of the steak too much for me. Regardless of the steak not being prepared to my liking, I would definitely come back to this restaurant!! The food was good.

This is a great place to enjoy dinner, and I would eat here again.

We will come back for sure.

text: Although I wasn't very familiar with Ethiopian cuisine, I had a great time at this restaurant. The food was absolutely delicious, and the price was very fair, especially considering that we ordered a platter for four people and couldn't even finish it! My friend really enjoyed the mango smoothie, but I found it a bit too sweet and heavy. The one downside was that the restaurant was very busy, and they occasionally forgot to bring our additional orders. Also, they charged us the wrong amount, so it's important to double-check your tab during checkout. However, despite these minor issues, the food was superb and definitely worth a visit for anyone in the area looking to try something new.

text:
Came for the Tuesday deal. Was told it would be 20-30min wait for leagues and parties to end. However, league doesn’t end until 9pm and about 3/4 of the lanes are dedicated to league games. We ended up waiting over and hour to bowl. Our issue is they knew league wouldn’t end until 9 and they gave us a complete unrealistic waiting time. Also multiple lanes (many next to each other) were completely open but they wouldn’t allow anyone to bowl next to league games. This is incredibly frustrating for local patrons who want to take advantage of their weekly deals. So disappointing. Also if you plan to have a night with a lot of people at the bar it would be nice to have more then one bartender to serve drinks took forever to get anything

Came back with a Groupon, just a heads up if you use a Groupon you have restrictions on your lane that are not listed.

text: It's been around 20 years since I've been bowling but this was my birthday so I decide to go with some family. Bowling hasn't changed, it's still really fun even if you can barely break 100. text: This is my favorite lanes here in Denver. The specials they have are decently priced and there are a lot of days where you can bowl for pretty cheap. I love the Sunday morning 10am to Noon games because it's only $2 a game which is really nice, my roommate almost bowled a 300 last Sunday. text:
The Denver Zoo is one of the best zoos I've been to. I would give it third place - behind only San Diego & the National Zoo. It's a very big zoo for being right in the city,  with easy access from downtown and 25. Admission is incredibly reasonable and is a better deal than the aquarium.  The enclosures are great and the animals seem very well cared for.  We did a "behind the scenes" with birds of pretty and it was excellent! Tons of great information the keepers were amazing and clearly loved the animals they work with.

100% recommend it!

text: We had a great time here. This zoo is much better than the Birmingham Zoo. I would rate the zoo five star, but several exhibits are closed for renovations. The elephant show was great. We were able to see one tiger. The other one was sleeping on a platform and only partially visible. We saw some lions, seals and sea lions. Our time was limited, so we did not see much else. If you need to leave and return the same day, then you can get your hand stamped and not have to pay to come back in on the same day.

text: First time doing the Denver Zoo light spectacular and it was absolutely remarkable. I love how they spread out different themes throughout the park ie: makes it look like you're walking through the ocean and another part like you're walking through the jungle. Over 1 million lights! Getting the glow pass and the zoo it all pass are great additions! The glow pass gives you 3-D glasses that are VERY fun & unique to view all the lights! That pass also gives you a nice insulated souvenir cup.  The Zoo it all pass gives you unlimited rides on the train,  carousel and 4-D show which is perfect for families of all ages. Perfect seasonal fun for the entire family.

I’d highly recommend going and I’d look forward to returning during warmer weather.

text:
I've been a zoo member for six years and a zoo volunteer for two years. I always enjoy my time at the zoo, even on snowy and cool days. You may not see every animal every time, but it's amazing the different animals and behaviors you do see depending on the time and temperature.

I highly recommend a zoo membership and timed tickets before the zoo opens to the general public. The cool mornings are great for the animals, especially Nikita the Amur tiger.

My daughter is too young to enjoy the animals but loves people watching every time we go.

text: The Denver Zoo is large with many different exhibits and animals. Any animal you want to see can be seen here for the most part. There is a lot of activities to do here for all age ranges including train rides, typical zoo food, a large area to walk around in nice weather, and beer. The gift shop is well stocked as well. The zoo is also a quick drive away from downtown as well which is convenient for going out afterwards. During the winter time, they also do an event called Zoo Lights where they hang lights all around the zoo to give a unique experience. Overall, I think this is a well-run zoo that is a fun time every time I visit.

text:
Really enjoyed this zoo. It was compact, walkable and had a wide range of species. Staff was friendly, ticket rates were reasonable ($15 for adults).

Located near Denver city park, it’s a short 5 min walk from the interesting musuem of science and nature which is yet another worthwhile attraction in this area. There’s ample parking here if you are renting a car, otherwise it’s pretty accessible via ride-based apps as well.

They have a number of lions and penguins greeting you as you enter and then a plenitude of primates likes orangutans, chimpanzees and gorillas waving at you from their large enclosures. Animals are well looked after here like in other zoos in LA, Oakland and San Diego and have a good amount of space to wander about so let your conscience not bother you for indulging at their price. They have a fascinating selection of reptiles (snakes) and fish in their indoor aquarium. Definitely recommend it.

They have a number of lions and penguins greeting you as you enter and then a plenitude of primates likes orangutans, chimpanzees and gorillas waving at you from their large enclosures. They have a fascinating selection of reptiles (snakes) and fish in their indoor aquarium. Definitely recommend it.

text:
We haven't been here in about a year and so much has changed! It was a great zoo before, but even better now. Plan to spend quite some time there. My daughter and I were just there for two hours and didn't get to see everything! It got too close to closing time lol. Will go earlier next time (went at 230 on a Saturday). The exhibits the animals are staying in are amazing. I was especially impressed with the elephant and giraffe houses. The way the place is set up and designed is awesome. And you can tell the care takers are really great and take loving care of their animals.

Random tips: We took our own water bottles. There are water bottle filling stations throughout the zoo so you don't have to purchase drinks if you don't want to. There is a water spray station for the kiddos if they get too hot. Some of the indoors exhibits are also air conditioned. Lots of places to rest or just observe the animals. I will say parking is tight when it's busy, so if you make a reservation, give yourself plenty of time to find parking. The garage is free and has four levels, elevators take a minute, walk the stairs if you're trying to get to the entrance for a reservation. City Park is also right next to the zoo and has an awesome play ground and places to picnic. Masks are not required, but some guests do wear them. I wore one because I'm high risk and was fine. Can't wait to go back! Hope the avian bird flu passes soon so the birds can come out, but gotta keep all the animals safe ❤️.

*Our passes were free through Denver Public Library. You have to make the reservations ahead of time online. I believe the prices are $20 for adults and $15 for kids 3 - 11, otherwise. It's worth it!

text: The zoo was really nice! I went on a day when the weather wasn't that great (which is my fault) so a lot of the animals were kind of hiding and what not. They have some parts under construction and the birds were all taken in for their own safety, so I feel like I didn't get the full experience, but I would love to go back and a day where everything is normal and it's nice out.

text: We had a great time at the Denver Zoo. We've lived here for more than five years, and this was our first time going. The zoo is much bigger than we had originally thought. They have a lot of animals, and it was pretty clean. There was a good amount of parking when we arrived at 10 in the morning, and parking was free. I recommend buying tickets in advance, so they can scan them at the entrance, and I recommend downloading the app. We didn't find out about the app until it was fairly late in our visit, and we may have missed some animals. We spent somewhere between two and three hours in the zoo (but could have been there longer if it wasn't so hot out); it was a fun day!

text:
It was a good time. I'd do it again.  I think it's best to start out with an easier room your first time. The room holds up to 8. So, keep in mind if you don't have a party of 8, you may have strangers added to your room.
We did the Gambler room. It was an 8/10 for toughness. It was tough. We did not breakout but were minutes away from doing so.
The clues are great! The staff is helpful.
I feel it's hard for everyone to have a chance at solving when there are that many. It kind of ends up being a few solving everything while the rest stand back feeling like they are in the way.
By the way, 5 year olds can attend but there is no price reduction. They are $30 just like everyone else.

text:
Update: Breakout KC to the Rescue. After sharing the rough experience, Breakout KC stepped up to make sure our group had the quality experience they are known for offering. My group came together and did Room 13. We enjoyed the entire puzzle and the great teamwork. The puzzle was fun and well put together. Most of all I enjoyed seeing all my friends work together for our last outing before we move.
Update: Recently I visited Breakout KC again, I had a less than stellar experience. My group was paired with a few ladies that made the evening not as much fun. They stole the puzzle experience from our group.
Oldest: We went as a team building event and they provided a great experience for us. The puzzle was well thought out with cool ideas. I really liked the physical portion of the puzzle. We did hero and saved the world. I will come back with my family and friends.

text:
I had so much fun!  Never wanted to do an escape room before, in fact... I was pretty adamant about not wanting to be locked in a room but... I'm hooked!
Breakout KC was a well organized, clean and creatively fun environment.
We went for a birthday surprise and the host rented two rooms; Room 13 and Szechuan Secret.  Our group had Room 13 and happy to say we figured out the puzzles with :46 seconds left.  Great fun, fantastic team work and excellent bonding time with friends!
Can't wait for my next visit!  Stay well and keep up the great work and creativity Breakout KC!
Xoxo Nichole Raab

The aquarium was very clean and didn’t smell of Ocean. The tour was only 1hr or so. Can’t wait to Return.

text:
I went with family - we brought children ages 5, 6, 7 & 10. The kids all enjoyed the experience.

Information: Park in the Crown Plaza and have your parking validated. Plan to spend 1-1.5 hours there. We were there just over an hour and saw everything. We purchased combo Legoland/Sea Life tickets.

Pros: They have a handout for the kids and “punch stations” throughout that encourage kids to read and learn about the animals and exhibits. There is a variety of sea life to look at, some very beautiful exhibits and the information is easy to read and understand - very age appropriate. There is a “touch” station and the kids enjoyed seeing what different creatures felt like.

Cons: I expected to need to spend more time here, it was actually quite small. One of the punch stations for the kids’ activity was out of order. The entire sea turtle display was closed. The final station had iPads available and about 5/15 of the iPads were on and working.

Final Thoughts: This was a neat experience, but once was enough. If you’re looking for an amazing aquarium and zoo experience, consider checking out the Henry Doorly Zoo in Omaha, Nebraska. You very well might want to plan 2 days (not hours) & you still won’t see everything!

text:
Came upon this place walking around Coronado Center as I hadn’t been there in a couple of years. What a surprise!

I love arcades, and this one blew my mind. A lot of the games are the Japanese versions which is amazing to find, especially in The Land of Enchantment.

I love claw machines(the more challenging the better), and this place has TONS of them.

I purchased a $40 card and after a few arcade tries I went to try a claw.

After about 10 tries my card ran out of money, and I went to go re-load it. While I was gone, the progress that I had made on the item in the machine was re-set by a worker, which led me to a mini-freakout.

Luckily, he saw me and apologized, opened the machine and placed the item back where it was and let me continue. After about six more tries, I won! The key with the Japanese claw machines is PATIENCE.

I hd a wonderful time at this place, and will definitely be back.

text:
Probably the best variety of arcade games in the region, including a lot of popular Japanese arcade games that unfortunately are untranslated. They have 2 DDR machines and a few other dance games, which, unfortunately are all next to each other so the music gets mixed badly. There is a good selection of shooting games, classic stuff like skeeball, fighting games etc.

They also have TONS of crane games, karaoke, a small bowling alley and a snack bar.

My biggest issue is their app is a dumpster fire that doesn’t work, causing you to need to go to the game card counter, which often only has one person working.

I will add more photos when I go back. I will be going back too.

text:
My first impression walking up was not good. However, not judging a book by its cover, I came in for a birthday party my 8yr old son was invited to. The facility was very crowded but the staff were trying their hardest to accommodate everyone. I don’t fault staff for that, I would rather them try to help rather than not care.

The pool area is fun for kids of all ages. I saw plenty of every age. The ONLY negative thing I would say is that it is extremely hot and humid inside. There was at least one 6ft tall fan blowing from one side which was nice but it’s only local air movement.

Overall I am/was impressed and would recommend this place to others. The air circulation or lack of is the only reason I didn’t give it 5 stars.

Whether you want to go to the bar with great local/ regional selections and a chill atmosphere, you want to take the kids someplace affordable to play games (not having to worry about the dreaded prize cabinet) or you just want to take time and REALLY work on your pinball or battle game skills... This place is for you! We love to bring guests or friends here for a night out or just kill some time affordably.

The only things we'd probably improve is the appetizer/ snack offerings to be more kid friendly on weekends, to have an awesome loyalty / membership or 'reserve a machine' type of program (members only early opening or play time would be sweet) and a better window covering near the pinball machines to reduce glare during the day (or move them in the back again/ get a bigger place)...
Otherwise it's STILL one of our favorites!

Otherwise it's STILL one of our favorites!

text:
I really like this setup. We went here for our work party and the person that set it up said it was very inexpensive. I don't know the exact price but I thought she said it was around $10 per table and then approx $5 per person and it's unlimited free play. You're given a wristband that will show you paid and then you can go in and out as you please.

The arcade is large and it's mainly games from the 80s. There were even games I'd never seen or heard of. The atmosphere was good and the food they served was very good. You also get 2 tickets for 2 free drinks. This is a good find for large group activities.

text:
My work involves a lot of travel and I’ve been fortunate to visit multiple arcades around the world, including Japan. I’d easily rank the four Free Play locations in the DFW metro area collectively as the best arcades I’ve visited in the United States. In fact, I think the fact they routinely acquire new games and swap out machines on the floor gives them an advantage over the few remaining retro Japanese arcades.

In short, THIS is how you do an arcade right. I hate the term “barcade” but I suppose this is one in the sense they have an impressive bar and kitchen on site. That said, unlike almost every other self-styled barcade I’ve visited, the drinks and food complement the games rather than serve as the primary attraction.

What sets Free Play apart is the diversity and rarity of its games. These feature some true gems on original hardware that go well beyond the dime-a-dozen Pac-Man and Centipede cabs found elsewhere. For example, the Richardson location (at the time of this writing) has an ultra-rare Planet Harriers, an Atomiswave running Dolphin Blue, the first Beast Busters, Do Don Pachi, Power Stone 2, and the original Marvel Vs. Capcom…to name just a few. I’m not really into pinball but there are quite a few of those machines on the floor too.

Whether you’re a serious arcade enthusiast or just a casual player who wants an afternoon with your kids, I can’t recommend Free Play enough.

text: The museum had many stages with monitors that show clips of a boat wreck story the museum portrays. The walk is about an hour-and-a-half and the tour is said to be the length of a football field (even though it doesn’t seem like it.) The large water wheel in the entrance is entirely displayed once you go down to the lower level of the museum, which is impressive. The wooden floors will give you the feeling of being inside an old-fashioned steam boat as it creaks and moves in a fragile state. They really did try to make an average boat wreck seem  like the wreck of the century, but I only really just saw average household & local shop items. The engine parts and excavation process was more interesting than the artifacts and that's just my opinion. There are about 2 staff members that are available to answer any questions about the tour and the . It’s not as lively, they can work on being more involved with the visitors. All-in-all, the museum was detailed and informative, not the most exciting though. They get a 3.5 from me.

text:
So many artifacts from this sunken steamboat! It's a fascinating window into a slice of life in the 1850s. Very cool to see the preservation work continuing. The self-paced tour begins with four stations that each play ~5-minute videos, then there's a longer video in a theater, then free range exploration of the rest of the museum. All of the videos are optional, or you can go back, if you just want to skip ahead to see the exhibits. Our group had some reductant museum-goers, but this offered a little something for everyone in our group: human interest stories, history in context, geology, science and engineering, arts and culture.

The gift shop is the beginning where you can purchase admission and the tour ends there as well. The staff members here were kind and informative. We parked in front of the museum (off Grand) and it was easy to pay for 2-hour parking online ($2.29), and that was just the right amount of time for our group. Worth a visit, especially if you want an outing with out-of-town guests.

text: I asked dear friends of mine who live in Kansas City what is one place I absolutely don't want to miss seeing here, their answer? - Arabia Steamboat Museum. It was well worth the price of admission ( and they have kids, seniors, and military discounts)! The best part was getting to see one of the men who dug it up and getting to have a conversation with another during our visit!! It was outstanding to see all the materials and supplies carried on just one steamboat. I never thought about the hundreds of steamboats, their passengers, and the amount of goods they supplied in building the frontier settlements. This museum is one of the best that brings life in the mid-1800s to life before your eyes. I want to come back again with my kids and parents!!

text: I was skeptical at first but I decided to give it a try and walked away feeling educated and impressed. The story of the Arabia Steamboat, her search team, their dedication and the time, money and effort they put in to locate the wrecked Arabia Steamboat and then share the valuable history with the public is amazing. This museum makes me want to learn more about steamboats as well as wreckage in the Missouri River. I would definitely recommend you check this place out if you are in the River Market area of KC.

text:
We made a visit to the Trap Museum during a very busy holiday weekend. Juneteenth. The line was wrapped around the building and up through the parking lot. New paragraph. You're going to need to pay to park unless you are going to risk it and park on the street. Parking is about $10.

Once you get in line no one let you know that you can pay for a VIP pass and skip the line for $20. Unless you asked about it you want no. We heard another lady asked about it and she was told that she could go to the front of the line for an additional $20 on top of the $20 he already paid.

It was so hot outside we paid the money. It is rather small, which definitely resemble the trap house, but it has great content and material inside. I thoroughly enjoyed our experience there. Lots of information and good artwork. I was just really love how they pay homage to so many different rapper and artist. The staff was very welcoming and hospitable oh, but the drinks at the bar were pretty high! Very potent, but pretty high LOL B Trap House granny was a highlight she was definitely a character walking through the house with her belt passing falls out and talking crazy. Like normal Grammys did back in the day LOL new paragraph. It was a great experience and I'm glad I was able to take my friend so she could enjoy that experience as well.

text:
Awesome experience! I did the trap museum and the escape room and it was worth the $45. The escape room is highly entertaining. The trap room is informative, you'll learn much about the King and other southern artist. My group spent about 2 hours in the escape room and trap museum. It's not very big but great to take pictures, it's s chill environment.
My only suggestion: change the parking lot. It is a very compact parking space, we weren't sure if we were supposed to park there due to lack of signs and how small it was. Attempting to get out was a disaster due to the small space and multiple cars. Overall I highly recommend visiting the Trap Museum and definitely partake in the Escape the Trap room.

text: I will say it's okay to see for the experience, but if im being honest, it's not much to this place. I dont understand why this place always has a line it just so happens that the day I went (Saturday /12 noon), it was a line, but it went quickly, roughly 5-10 min.  They charge $20 to get in this place, not worth it, in my opinion . the tickets you purchase  online never expire (my sister bought 2 tickets in the year 2020 that we used for this day). overall, it is a cool place to check out if you're visiting Atlanta and tryna find something to check out. This place does have a candy store, which I found to be an interesting twist & a bar inside. I give the place 3 stars due to: You get to see real trap house, you get to see some history of some big name Trap stars, you get to take photos with props and the candy store bar was a nice touch.

text: The Trap Museum was the bomb!! If you love Rap (Trap Music) then this is definitely worth paying a visit atleast once. The tickets were only $20 but we had to pay $20 to park (cash only). We went on a Sunday and got there about 30 minutes before they opened and the line had already started to form outside the building. I'd recommend arriving early because when we left the line was pretty intimidating. (You will be patted down fellas and for the ladies they check your purses so leave ya artillery & Everythang else at da hize) BOL 🤣  All of the exhibits were astonishing! I was extremely excited to finally get a chance to visit "The Trap". They have a bar inside, an Escape room that you can purchase tickets for, as well as a shop as you leave out where you can purchase Trap Museum tshirts starting at $25.

Finally, don't forget to trade in your arcade points for Awesome well valued prizes and candy before you go. Frankie's! TRY IT OUT. P.S. try the "virtual hyper deck" a fun experience!

text:
For the price point (a little over $100) it was a very good experience. The mattress was perfect, 4 fluffy clean pillows, blankets and bedding were clean and smelled lovely.
The carpets were also clean and didn't feel gross when you walked on it barefoot. The bathroom was also clean but a star lost for the condition of the tub. It was very oddly shaped and slippery when I was taking a shower, BE CAREFUL!
The general smell of the hotel was clean and pleasant when you walked in, what a nice surprise! There is a decent FREE breakfast bar in the morning but come early to avoid the herds.
Check in was done professionally if not overly friendly. The hotel is located on a dead end but strangely, it's a very peaceful and quiet place. 4 ☆☆☆☆ We will def come back to stay when we're in KC.

text:
This hotel is all hype and no substance. If you like ridiculously tiny overpriced rooms with concrete walls then this place is for you. We walked into an 80 degree room because their AC was on the fritz. Didn’t cool down till late at night. One entire wall is a floor to ceiling window so by noon you have to use the blackout shade to keep the room cool. So then it feels like you’re in a prison cell.
Location is great but otherwise too many cons:
- mandatory valet parking at $46/night.
- weak AC and water pressure
- room is so tiny with barely a closet and no dressers so you have no place to put your things. Barely have a place to walk.
- the blackout curtains don’t work properly and suddenly go up and down on their own.
- hotel is on Wilshire so tons of street noise (windows are not sound proofed)
- construction going on next door
- plumbing is terrible
- gym is tiny in relation to the size of this hotel (as well as their pool).

It’s just not worth it for what they charge. Definitely not a place you want to stay at for more than a night or two. The tv is so high and can’t be adjusted to tilt down. They really haven’t put the guest at the forefront of their design decisions.

text:
I stayed one night at The LINE Hotel on Wilshire to attend the Blackpink concert at Banc of California stadium on Nov. 20. It was a short visit as I flew in from Honolulu on the 20th and arrived at the hotel around 4:30pm. Whoa, a pretty eclectic place ... very industrial, loft-ish style with bare concrete walls and austere furnishings. My room was on the smallish size with a small, but perfectly adequate bathroom, a very small closet and just enough seating for two. The bed faced the floor-to-ceiling wall of glass overlooking Wilshire Boulevard. There is a wall-mounted TV and power shades for privacy.

The concert was at 8pm and I arranged a ride at 5:30pm so I went to the bar for a drink. It's a nice space but there was a limited selection of gins so I ordered a Hendricks gin and tonic. A perfectly fine drink, albeit at a price. As this is a review of the hotel, I'll omit anything related to the concert.

I returned at midnight and wanted to find a place to have some drinks and dinner but it was too late. So, I had to make do with whatever I had in my duffle bag (cookies) and retired for the night. The bed is comfortable though the noise from the street was somewhat intrusive.

The next morning I went down to the 2nd floor where the Openaire Restaurant is located. It's a bright, airy space with a large bar on one side. I had the LINE breakfast: two eggs, pancakes, chicken sausage and cottage potatoes. The eggs were somewhat underdone but the breakfast was fine; at least for an hour. I spent the remainder of my stay in the bathroom in my room ... something in the breakfast didn't agree with me. I do have a sensitive stomach but the only thing I could think of were the undercooked eggs. Oh well, 2 hours later I felt better and checked out to return to LAX and flew back to Honolulu.

Final thoughts ... I like the hotel and its location but I think at least one of the bars should stay open past 10pm. This is LA, not Honolulu. Would I return? Yes, I would, in spite of my issues with my breakfast.

text:
The interior design is really nice, and the big window makes the room to feel more spacious (or the room is actually quite small for the price).

Slippers are provided in the room, and there are many plugs the room for you to charge whatever devices you have.

Nevertheless, the air conditioner is constantly going on and off; it is not only noisy, but it also keeps changing the room temperature from too hot to too cold.

Sound proof is not great - you can hear a lot of noises from the streets at night.

Overall, it was a nice experience for a one-night stay (because I really do love the big window). But if you’re not such a big fan of big windows, I suggest somewhere else to stay.

text:
I would give negative stars if something of that sort was there. I would like to show some  pictures before really describing about the service because this is what a “4-star” hotel in  Los Angeles ,USA  can offer.
Are they mocking on themselves or us?
Because I haven’t  had such a terrible service in my lifetime !!!!!
1)We find this 4-star hotel and see that we need to pay for parking when their website actually shows free parking under amenities.
2)We had a long 9hrs journey and we were relocating so we had lot of stuff as luggage and happen to check in by 10.30pm.We told the front desk that we are really tired and what they offered was a trolley and we had to carry entire luggage ourselves, explanation was “we don’t have anybody” when they are supposed to have somebody for customers “all the time”.RIDICULOUS!!!!Clearly shows LACK OF EMPATHY.
Well we carried our own luggage since we were super tired to find another hotel.
3)We got into room and we see our bath shower is worn off and broken.
4)No kettle which is like a very basic thing to make coffee in morning, we asked and receptionist could tell us there is a cafe which will be opened by 6.30am.Clearly shows RUNNING FROM RESPONSIBILITY
5)Now I didn’t know 4 star hotels started keeping open plastic bucket as waste bins in bathrooms.SERIOUSLY!!!!!
6)And the funniest out of all is they have kept a big basket with snacks chocolates, nuts, water and I was skeptical about it and I just called up to know if they come as complementary. Well it seems it is kept to tempt the people to use it and they will charge for every single thing during checkout .
7)Even 2-star hotels actually have hair dryers, kettle and covered waste bins in bathroom.

I don’t even know what to say .Can’t believe I’m given such a terrible service in a developed country like USA.

OBNOXIOUS TRAUMATISED EXPERIENCE OF LIFETIME

Because I haven’t  had such a terrible service in my lifetime !!!!!
1)We find this 4-star hotel and see that we need to pay for parking when their website actually shows free parking under amenities.
2)We had a long 9hrs journey and we were relocating so we had lot of stuff as luggage and happen to check in by 10.30pm.We told the front desk that we are really tired and what they offered was a trolley and we had to carry entire luggage ourselves, explanation was “we don’t have anybody” when they are supposed to have somebody for customers “all the time”.RIDICULOUS!!!!Clearly shows LACK OF EMPATHY.
Well we carried our own luggage since we were super tired to find another hotel.
3)We got into room and we see our bath shower is worn off and broken.
4)No kettle which is like a very basic thing to make coffee in morning, we asked and receptionist could tell us there is a cafe which will be opened by 6.30am.Clearly shows RUNNING FROM RESPONSIBILITY
5)Now I didn’t know 4 star hotels started keeping open plastic bucket as waste bins in bathrooms.SERIOUSLY!!!!!
6)And the funniest out of all is they have kept a big basket with snacks chocolates, nuts, water and I was skeptical about it and I just called up to know if they come as complementary. Well it seems it is kept to tempt the people to use it and they will charge for every single thing during checkout .
7)Even 2-star hotels actually have hair dryers, kettle and covered waste bins in bathroom.

I don’t even know what to say .Can’t believe I’m given such a terrible service in a developed country like USA.

OBNOXIOUS TRAUMATISED EXPERIENCE OF LIFETIME

text: We booked this hotel because it was close to where my friend lived. I must say I totally lucked out. From the moment I walked in I could tell it was my kind of place. The  lobby had a great vibe, it almost reminded me of a boutique hotel in New York City. The staff made eye contact with me at the front desk from the second I walked in and were eager to check me in. I stayed in a one bedroom king bed studio overlooking the Hollywood Hills. The room was very clean and I will definitely be going back to this hotel next time I’m in Los Angeles! I walked down to the pool but I didn’t go in. There was an awesome restaurant down there and a great vibe in the pool, I wish I had more time to spend there but I just went to check it out.

text:
The worst hotel ever. I would rather stay in a best westin that has proper close and double glazed windows than in a hotel room that had zero insulation which made me felt like I was experiencing the LA desert weather as a homeless.
Since the windows don’t even close properly, you can hear everything on the streets at all time. I could not fall asleep at ease and was shivering every night while I was there.
The hotel is also not hygienic as a self-proclaimed 4-star hotel.
It also charges resort fees. Was there a beach with towel service I missed?

The manager ghosted me after me emailing him about how cold I was overnight and could not sleep. The front staff did the best they could by switching me to another room that also had a broken windows. At that point, I was too exhausted. I didn’t book a hotel to be packing and unpacking my suitcase everyday.

If you want proper rest, this hotel is really not it. But if you don’t need to sleep and don’t mind the cold desert night weather. This might be your cup of tea.

text:
Very hipster/modern vibe to the entire hotel including the common and private areas. The rooms have concrete walls and automatic open/close blackout and sheer Roman blinds to manage the light from the massive full wall window which is essential if u have a view of the Hollywood sign which I did in my King room.

The room was also fit for tech and the inputs for the tv were located in a panel on the top of the desk. I was able to connect my PlayStation 5 and my laptop easily to display on the TV.

The staff was helpful and helped me thru getting my business trip authorization forms to properly charge my business card and holding my bags for me until checkin as the room took a while to be ready for checkin.

Lots of interesting things to do daily from the happy hours at the hotel bar to an array of bars nearby that cater to hotel guests including a speakeasy(if ur adventurous enuf to find it)

There is a rooftop restaurant that is in a greenhouse near the pool. The food is on par price wise with hotel restaurants. This was scenic during sunrises.

There are a couple of art installations including murals and 3-D art inside and out. Artsy and explorers will want to have a bit of free time to roam around and take pictures.

Not much parking the valet stand is quite monopolizing of most of what should be parking but this is to be expected in this part of the city, koreatown. Avoid the crowd use the side door.

text: My experience at the LINE LA was okay at best, from the moment I arrived  valet parking was $44 a night +tax to the end when I found a roach in our room. Everything in between was Motel Quality, from the damp rooms to the Carpets and bathroom being dingy and rundown, not the 4 star experience they are claimed to be or what the pictures online depict. The only redeeming parts of the stay were the ice machine actually working (To my surprise) and the staff being friendly and understanding.

text: This is a great hotel and one of the more affordable ones in LA. The service is great and everyone is super nice and professional. Got early check-in and was given late check out after requesting it at no extra charge!

text:
Nice hotel. Enjoyed our stay. Good if you want to be in k-town. Although as it pitched itself as this new cool trendy hotel its lacking a few things:
1. the latest style of watching TV. No on demand or netflix etc. The connections to attach you device didn't work and didn't have the ability to connect latest Android devices.
2. Noise insulation from outside and noise between rooms. We were women in the middle of the night by noisy neighbours 2 nights. And the Windows are really thin and let on noise and drafts.
3. Service although friendly in general wasn't up to the standard of say a hotel like The Ace.

What was good was:
The room was comfortable.
The view from the room was great of the Hollywood hills.
Cool room design
The reception staff were good

text:
Better then some hotels but could be better overall.
Checked in easily. But the key card stopped working when we left the room the first time and had to come back twice to get a replacement.
We weren't told to keep our phones away from the card until the third replacement.
We left for 3 hours and turned the AC down while gone.  Came back and the room was so hot we almost threw up packing up our stuff.
They then gave us a different room after we had to carry everything which took us 2 trips the first time down to the lobby back to the 5th floor. They did give us free breakfast for the inconvenience but would of been nice if they could of met us on the floor instead of 2 trips down to get the room and 1 trip with the luggage cart up.
Breakfast was so so half of the buffet was kinda cold. Wouldn't pay for it so for a free breakfast it's decent.
They also didn't explain any charges so I had a mini panic attacks that they charged me an extra 100 for my room only to go down and have the free explained
Overall a little bit mismanaged. But the greeter is super nice and the breakfast servers have great service.

I'll just travel further  if I have to stay in this area.

text:
It was my first time staying at a hostel and I'm glad it was at this location, close to the lake in a nice area. Compared to many a 1-star motel or hotel, it's bare bones in room amenities, but the sense of community and the savings are good reasons to consider staying in one. What comes to mind is a boarding house, which I suppose hostels are akin to, but the staff at this place are helpful and responsive to guest needs and concerns. We enjoyed the complimentary breakfast and the nice patio area. Our fellow guests were from various places and the ones we met were friendly.

Nearby are many nice restaurants, cafes, businesses, conveniences, and bars. To the east is the North Pond, and further the lake shore. You can walk, run, or bike to your heart's content (convenient for pet owners too as it's very pet friendly in the area). It's less than 15 minutes away from the conservatory and the zoo (both free). There are are wonderful museums both in the area and a little further away (but in stone's throw).

Tips: 1) bring your own food to store in the plentiful refrigerated cases (they provide bins and labels) to save on dining expenses or if you have specific dietary requirements. 2) Their parking spaces are limited so arrive within 5 minutes of check-in. It's $28 a night to park there. 3) Alternatively, use an app like SpotHero to book affordable longer term spaces in the area (12 hours to a several days). 4) the kitchen is huge and well maintained, but do your part to help keep it that way (same goes for the bathrooms). 5) if you're looking for fun things to do, check out the activities chalkboard in the lobby. 6) Be respectful, kind, and friendly to everyone there. You will get out of the experience what you put into it.

text: Its price and breakfast are unbeatable! I LOVE its breakfast the most. You can have well-toasted toast or waffles, hot oatmeal, boiled eggs, milk with cereals, hot coffee, and fruits! The public space is comfy and spacious. The kitchen is professionally well-equipped. However, I dislike its "remote" shared restrooms.... You have to walk through doors to get there. The water from the sink faucets is quite slow. The shower rooms have no racks inside to put my stuff. But other than that, I like it, and I would definitely come back again for it's breakfast and its spaciousness. Oh, it takes a relaxing10-min walk from the subway station (Fullerton), and an 8-min walk to Target and all great diners & Starbucks!

text: Very pleasant stay. The rooms were small, but very clean. Bathrooms are shared, but also very clean. The staff were very accommodating, exceptionally polite, and helpful (thank you, Joaquin!). The hostel is located in a very quiet neighborhood right off Clarke Ave (5 minute walk). There are a ton of different restaurants and food choices. DO NOT miss Bourgeois Pig for coffee and breakfast! Angela's Burrito Style for lunch or late night dinner. And House of Hunan if you're feeling Chinese. There is also a Walgreens for any travel items you might have missed. All the other guests we ran into were polite and we had no issues with anything. Thank you CGH for making this adventure completely amazing!!

text:
*stayed here in August*

First time staying at a hostel and I was a bit disappointed. The room was a lot smaller than I thought it would be, it was for three people and it got a bit cramped. It was the private one and almost costed $400.

The parking was a big issue for us since we didn’t get a chance to pay for the parking at the hostel. Eventually we found a lot to park in a few minutes away.

The bathrooms were okay, they were clean which was nice.

My sister got the breakfast and did not enjoy it.

The person at the front counter was nice.

Overall I might come stay here again IF I was traveling alone but will probably check out the other hostels in a Chicago first.

text: A hidden gem!!! Clean rooms, theater room, giant kitchen, game room. I stayed 3 days my tab was $47. I stayed in a 12 bed dorm room that was only occupied by 5 people. There are lockers in every room. I would have liked to see a fitness area but it doesn’t exist. Laundry room in the basement was a little creepy but I was grateful it was there. They popped free popcorn and had an event board. The hostel gets 5 stars for safety! You have to tap your card to get in many of the doors. They provided dishes to cook on I enjoyed my stay. Oh yeah and I fell in love with the giant mirror

text: Great hostel in a great area. We stayed in a premium crash pad with the en suite. It’s sleeps up to 5 people but it was just 2 of us. It includes a bunk bed with two twins, as well as a bunk bed with a twin on top and a full on bottom. The room was smaller but would work for 5 people, because there is a nice walk in closet to store plenty of suitcases. The en suite was nice, there was a desk, a mini fridge, a bean bag, as well as a window AC unit. The room was clean, cool and comfortable. The only and biggest complaint/warning is the pillows were terrible. BRING YOUR OWN PILLOW! But definitely worth a try.

text:
The place is in a cool neighborhood. I didn't get a chance to explore, since I was mostly downtown. With that said, this location wasn't centrally located.
The people at the front desk are really nice. The lobby area, movie area, and kitchen are really great.
My room was clean. I even received a room with a 1/2 bath.
The problem? The walls are paper thin. I was woken at 2am by a rowdy bunch, a guy that kept yelling at the top of his lungs that he was drunk and wanted to be taken advantage of. I was woken at 3am with someone in the next room hurling their guts out for what seemed like 20 min.
The bed was squeaky and didn't seem stable.
There was a huge dip in the mattress that I kept falling into. You felt every little spring in your back. Needless my back is killing me.
You essentially get what you pay for here.
Everything else was great. This place just isn't for me

text: This place is an oasis in one of California’s most beautiful regions. While you’re 5-10 minutes from the city, shops and restaurants, you feel like you’re in a remote country getaway. The terraces open up to fresh wooded air, quiet, and beautiful gardens with swans and flowing creek. It’s something quite magical. The rooms are modern and the staff is off the charts helpful and friendly. I came here to do a stop over from a road Trip and brought my bike with me. There are some great rides along Mulholland Dr, through the canyons, Griffith Park and Santa Monica beachside ride. So if you like the outdoors, this is yet another reason to stay here. It’s my favorite  destination in California along with the Ritz Carlton in Santa Barbara.

text: Hidden treasure just 2 km south of Onanole and within a few minutes you are in Riding Mountain National Park.  Uniquely decorated Bed and Breakfast - lots of interesting antiques in this house.  They have 11 rooms available for rent.  Very reasonable rates for the area.  The hot breakfasts we had were well prepared - the hostess would offer different choices and took into account allergies or preferences.  We enjoyed the cheese omelette.  Nice selection of teas.  The hostess offered a cheese platter as well - extra cost - for an evening snack or appetizer.  Fresh ingredients.  The bed was very comfortable.  Some rooms have the west facing view for great sunset views.  Clean bathroom.  There are no TVs in the individual rooms - not a problem - just be conscious of this.  There is a common room with a TV down the hall for all the guests.  Wifi was decent for the area.

text: One of our rooms was supposed to have a full over queen bunk but it was full over full...made it kinda inconvenient. But we had lots of couch space for people to sleep. We had a 4 bedroom condo and a 2 bedroom hospitality suite but only got 10 water park passes...they tried only giving me 8. It should have been 12 (2 per room...6x2=12) we had to buy 6 additional. No frying pans in the hospitality suite...we were done cooking breakfast by the time they brought us some. No extra toiletries, not enough for 17 people between the 5 units. Water park closed down a few times but we brought enough games to keep ourselves busy. We REALLY appreciated that they kept on top of keeping kids out of the hot tub! Fun arcade, friendly desk staff. Resort is kept up pretty well. Loved the layout of the hospitality suite, plenty of room for all of our guests to gather together, loved having the lawn outside the room to use as well.

text: Wonderful dog friendly rooms with hard to find water view balconies! We stayed in the more recently built building that is further from the outdoor pool. Clean, comfortable, spacious. The room does not provide seating (chairs, benches) inside the room other than the bed. However 2 patio chairs and small side table can be found on balcony. Quiet, relaxing, with an incredible television. Large king size bed was extremely easy to snuggle in and get awesome sleep. Water park passes (located in the other resort building) were included with our room price, but we did not have a need for those. There is no price adjustment if you do not need or use water park passes.  Also be aware: the water views are most definitely disappointing due to the building structures built between the hotel and the lake, obstructing the quality of the vacationer's view (and the roof air conditioning units constantly running in front of our rooms) but we adjusted.  Just not your standard open air, full Lakeshore experience we look for when vacationing by water. Certainly a top notch dog friendly stop when in the area! Highly recommend!
